moves.1. e4 b6: I experimented with an offbeat opening just to learn to play different kinds of positions.
moves.2. d4 Bb7 3. Bd3 e6 4. Nf3 d5 5. e5 g6 6: So far I am not very happy with my position because having to fianchetto both bishops loses a lot of tempos.
moves.7. Nc3 Nd7 8. b4 Ne7 9. Bg5: Now I am really not happy, as I will need to take several moves to unpin my N.
moves.9... O-O 10. a4 Re8 11. b5 Qc8 12. a5: I see one practical, possible problem for White.  The c3N is undefended.  LPDO (loose pieces drop off).
moves.12... bxa5 13. Rxa5 c5 14. bxc6 e.p. Nxc: Here I might have an opportunity to sneak a pawn.
moves.15... Nxd4 16. Nxd4 Qxc3 17. Nb5 Qxe5: This might not have been the best route to take.  It might have been simpler to stop the N fork on c7, give up the a pawn, and snag the e pawn later.
moves.18. Re1 Qxa1: The straightforward QxBg5 might have been less complicated.
moves.22. Nc7 Ne5 23. Nxe8 Rxe8 24. Rxa7: Now I've given back most of the material.  If I had played more simply, I could be up the exchange.
I'm up a pawn, but I don't have a good feel for how to win this endgame.  More study needed!
